instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message:
SMC bypass - no response


All voltages steady
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.41V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 0V

Slight corrosion around:
<CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/20, <RESISTOR>R3702</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3700</CAPACITOR>

Quite a corrosion between <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3770</CHIP>, also <CHIP>U8440</CHIP>

All coils diode modes seem ok, comparing to a working board. Apart than:
                  Faulty Board  | Working Board
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_SW1</SIGNAL> -      0.0083 | 0.0122
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_SW2</SIGNAL> -      0.0083 | 0.0122
<SIGNAL>SAVR_SW</SIGNAL>     -       0.0146 | 0.0266
<SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G_REG</SIGNAL> - 0.0712 | 0.245
<SIGNAL>PPVCCPCH_S5G</SIGNAL>  0.0725 | 0.267


Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message:
Latest values are too high comparing with good board.
You may have bad solders, due to corrosion.
I hope all readings are with red probe at ground.
Compare the values on all big coils; use ohm scale for very low values.

Check output voltages of <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> (7 OF 10), page 60.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message:
Yes, red probe to ground. Values of other coils are very close if not identical to the good board.

Will touch up the corroded lines. No falling off components while poking around.

Outputs of 7/10 <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_PDO3V</SIGNAL> - 3.21V
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_VREF</SIGNAL> - 1.21V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_LDO5V</SIGNAL> - 4.91V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message:
Now after replacing <CAPACITOR>C3706</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3708</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3700</CAPACITOR>
Fixing corrosion on pads of <RESISTOR>R3771</RESISTOR>/2, <RESISTOR>R2892</RESISTOR>/3
Lifting and resoldering <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>/1 

I get 5V 0.02A. Not detecting any short on the bigger coils, nor on the pads of the components, I replaced/resoldered

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message: Check <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message:
Need to get back <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> first.
I bet for more corrosion damage...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message:
Ok got the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> back. Who knew missing <SIGNAL>TBT_X_ROM_HOLD_L</SIGNAL> would cause <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> not to get to 20V

Im back to 20V 0.04A with:

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.41V
<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> - 0.462V
<SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> - 0V

There is no liquid signs around <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message: Check diode mode at <SIGNAL>3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> - 0.047 on this board - 0.462 on a good board. NO visible corrosion or liquid near <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.

My only donor board reads 0.0021 on <SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL>, that's probably not good for <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> swap if needed? On the other side, <SIGNAL>PP3V_G3H_PCH_VCCRTC</SIGNAL> goes into the CPU. Lost cause?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message:
Yeah, CPU, or <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> problem.
Just in case, remove <CAPACITOR>C1227</CAPACITOR>/28 and <CAPACITOR>C7922</CAPACITOR>.
If still low value, you can try to heat <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and/or CPU; hoping is accumulated crap issue.
At the end, removing <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is also an idea...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message:
With lifted up  <CAPACITOR>C1227</CAPACITOR>/28 and <CAPACITOR>C7922</CAPACITOR>  I get 20V 0.46A and the board is turning on. I Resoldered back then and still seems to turn on. 
Back in the case fan spins but no picture or response from the keyboard. Tried SMC reset, doesn't completely do it. 0.45A -> 0.02 -> 0.45A . Usually, I can see all zeroes on current and restarting the charger when I do SMC reset.

Reflowed <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, still no picture. Not sure if it got reflowed ok, hard to make it dance. 
I Can see the CPU gets hot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message: What is the final CPU core voltage?

threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G_PH1</SIGNAL> - 0.95V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCCPU_S0G_PH2</SIGNAL> - 0.95V
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0G</SIGNAL> - 1.02V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message:
Looks like stuck in 0.95V.
It should drop to 0.6V, when the board boots.

Possibly PCH/CPU issue.
Try known good BIOS, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message: can I swap from a good board? Haven't done bios flashing on a never macs before

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message:
It should work, for test.
If is BIOS issue, then finally need to clean ME region.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0.04A after liquid damage
threads.message: 20V 0.03A - 0.11A with spare bios chip from the same model board. Soldered <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> back and getting 20V 0.03A - 0.11A as well.  Maybe you are right, corroded or cold joint somewhere
